Authors: Jeffrey Patrick Rose, John V. Freudenstein
Title:
Cryptic and Overlooked: Species Delimitation in the
Mycoheterotrophic Monotropsis (Ericaceae: Monotropoideae)
Keywords:
Endemism, Ericaceae, Monotropsis, morphometrics,
mycoheterotrophy, species delimitation
Abstract:
Most recent treatments of Monotropsis recognize a single
species of achlorophyllous, mycoheterotrophic herb endemic to the
southeastern U. S. A. (M. odorata), although four species have been
described. This study reevaluates these proposed taxa using a
comprehensive approach to species delimitation analyzing variation in
morphology, phenology, geography, nuclear DNA, and chloroplast DNA.
Principal components analysis of morphometric data reveals two clusters
that are geographically distinct. These groups also correspond to clades
resolved with nuclear (ITS/26S and Xdh) and plastid (rpl32Â–trnL) DNA that
are furthermore distinct phenologically. These data support recognition
of M. reynoldsiae, a Florida endemic and recognition of M. odorata, an
Appalachian endemic. Furthermore, Monotropsis lehmaniae, proposed based
on an autumn flowering period and floral differences, is shown to
comprise individuals that are not yet in anthesis and should not be
recognized. Cryptophila pudica, named based on its disjunct geographical
distribution and floral differences, is also shown to be indistinct. A
taxonomic revision of the genus is presented.
